Name: QED: The Strange Theory of Light and Matter (Princeton Science Library)

ReviewList.Text: Even though these lectures are more than 20 years old, Feynman did an incredible job of explaining a fundamental concept in Physics.  I can see now why he received the Nobel prize for his work in this area.  I would call him the Carl Sagan of Physics, except that Mr. Sagan's popularity came later in time.  QED is so bizarre and incredible, yet so accurate and powerful a theory that it boggles the mind!  Mr. Feynman's explanation is so complete and articulate that anyone can understand it.  This theory explains the physical underpinnings of most of our daily experience, the interactions of photons with matter, yet it is a complete surprise!
I have given this book to several very talented HS students. It can be understood even without higher math.

I was recommended this book by a good friend of mine who actually worked with Feynman as well as Feynman's sister, also a brilliant scientist. It's short, terse, and brilliantly clear. Feynman must have tried to explain quantum mechanics to an awful lot of people over his career - he certainly got very good at it. Then, he wrote it down in this book. All the analogies are perfect and clear, all the explanations are pithy but understandable. Feynman isn't trying to dazzle you with his knowledge - he's trying to move knowledge from his brain to yours, and he succeeds.

One of the great books of the 20th Century...the first two chapters can be understood by anybody and should be read by everybody.  Like Einstein's THE EVOLUTION OF PHYSICS the content of QED might be  relavent to those interested in physics but the ways in which the problems are attacked constitute a  textbook on how to think creatively.  These lectures are really about how to develop cognitive strategies and point out that skills are sort of useless if one doesn't have the strategies by which they are appropriately employed.

I gave it a max. rating because it explains everything. You do need to know something about Physics but the author does explain it. Very good book, and I recommend it for those who are looking for more information. The book arrived in mint condition and a very enjoyable read. (sbuckley52@yahoo.ca)

Interesting, but like much of Quantum physics leaves me not quite understanding. Feyman does a good job of explaining but I don't think the lectures transfer well to the book format and especially the Kindle format.

Feynman is so masterful that he makes everything perspicuous.  The book tells you what complex numbers (those things that you learned in high school) are for (amongst other things of course).  It also tempts you to interpret the quantum nature of light - but you have also been warned by Feynman not to (page 9).  You will have the chance of having Feynman himself explaining Feynman diagrams.  You will learn that things can travel backwards in time (page 97) - or do they? You will also comprehend how all the three forces (electromagnetic, weak and strong) are inter-related (pages 136-142).  And towards the end, Feynman will try to marvel you with the elegance of nature and its imbued mystery.  Truly a masterpiece!

In this age of new discoveries in fundamental physics he is sorely missed. The book is compelling not because he is a great explainer but because he seems to fundamentally understand more clearly. So he has no fear in describing the limits of theories or knowledge - many popularizers are not true scientists and it is tricky for them to tell the difference between their own limits and the actual limits of the theories. - to reveal that there is *no* physical intuition at the quantum level - just laws. And we want those laws to be as elegant and simple and true to experiment as possible.

I highly recommend this book to anyone wanting to know more about quantum mechanics.  I've had two undergraduate courses in quantum.  The point of view expressed here is very different than the way those classes were taught.  It helps me to understand the computations I was doing in those classes.  This is a very practical book which explains how to think about problems in quantum mechanics and how to solve them.  This book would also be suitable for the lay person who wants to understand how quantum mechanics is used without having to learn all the equations and do all the calculus.

Feynman plunges his fist through the chest of QED and removes its very heart, without the use of a single surgical instrument.  This work is a beautifully tactful and simplistic exposition of the complex and wildly counter-intuitive characteristics of quantum electrodynamics.  For the novice, "QED" should introduce the notion of "summing over paths" as a way of making sense of the ludicrous tangle of quantum reality; to the expert, it should serve as a crisp example of how a difficult subject can be presented with clarity.

I have read a number of popular books on quantum mechanics and they generally  fall into two two categories:  simple glosses that fail to give you any real understanding of the subject or highly technical books that would require an advanced degree in physics to understand.  This book strikes a nice balance.  It doesn't attempt to be a comprehensive coverage of quantum mechanics, but gives an explanation of QED such that a reasonably intelligent reader could hope to come away with some real understanding.

This is an example of Richard Feynman at his most engaging and informative.  Drawn from a series of lectures, QED stands as an excellent introduction to the basic concepts of quantum electrodynamics for the lay audience. Feynman brings this at-times daunting area of physics into everyday experience for the non-researcher in a manner that is both enlightening and witty.  For those who only know Feynman from his memoir, "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman,"  this book is a real treat.

This is Feynman showing how brilliant he is by accurately explaining one of the most complicated areas of knowledge in a way understandable to most people without being dishonest with the subject matter.  Seeing how the reflectivity of light relates to Archimedes's insights into triangles not only avoids a complicated mathematical approach but provides an insight into how the reflections calculations relate to seemingly unrelated topics.

Step by step Feynman explains the relationship of light and matter. Starting with simplified models of reality, later on more tuned in to the real thing matters (no pun intended) become clear, even for a physics layperson like myself. Highly recommended reading!
I already have a hard copy but wanted to refresh my thoughts on it while travelling. A really neat way of looking at light that I really wish I had had while a student.

A very hard book to follow in its totality, but nevertheless gives a better glimpse into the nature of quantum mechanics than the other attempts that I have come across. Will need to re-read it a couple of times.
I've bought this book in order to get an introduction into QED. It turned out to be the best choice - the focus is on concept. A brilliant book.
This book does a good job of doing just what Dr. Feynman set out to do: to explain quantum electrodynamics in a way that those without any background can grasp.
Wenether you have a scientific background or not, if you want to understand something about light an quantum theory, this book is fot you !
Come read about the strange zoo of atomic and subatomic particles, their interaction and partially how this universe works, well partially at least :)

We take the simple things in life for granted and in the case of light, it turns out that what we regard as common-place and prosaic is as deep as the bottom of an ocean trench and about as well understood by the average layperson...this little book takes its reader into a little-known realm and gives a hint of just how ignorant we truly are!

An exquisitely challenging yet rewarding book if one is able to understand Feynman's theory of QED as presented in this text.  To be pithy, this book isn't exactly beach reading material, unless you're similar to this reader in which case, geeks/nerds shall inherit the universe +/- multi-verse.

I'm an enthusiastic amateur, with little or no formal physics education, however, I found this book to be interesting and - after a little re-reading - understandable too! If you aren't fascinated by the subject matter then there is something the matter with you!

Loved it. Changed my view of the world. Drawn in by the simple explanations of the complex subject, I found myself flashing back to high school and college science courses and how I might have become a physicist had I been exposed to this sooner.

The best way to learn about high end Physics for people with little background in the subject. The best way to drum up enthusiasm about the subject. Simply the best Physics book I have ever read ... so far! The clue is in the title.

I'm still slogging my way through this one. Quantum physics is not a trivial subject. Still, I find the book to be interesting and I am getting something out of it, which I suppose is pretty good given the subject.
It is a series of lectures written for the novice.  He shows how QED is thought about and how to solve simple problems.  I am surprised, however, that he accepts the backwards movement of time.
This is not a textbook by any means. However, it is extremely well written and I must say that currently it is my favorite book to just pick up and read for an educational and fun time.
QED is one of the best physics books I have read,  The play should be very interesting.  The book offers insight to Feynmans development of the path integral. He was truly a genius.
A really good "appetizer" on the subject. You don't need to be waist deep in quantum mechanics to read this text, but you'll want to go further after reading it. No doubt.
I thoroughly enjoyed this book!  Feynman's works are always readable, informative and very enjoyable.  QED is no exception to this.  Great introduction to quantum electrodynamics!
I don't know whether anyone other than Feynman can pull off QED in just 4lectures. This becomes more significant considering the fact that he starts from ground zero.
This is a great book for understanding the phase relationship of electromagnetic radiation.  Feynman finds a way to explain the concept without a lot of math.
Feynman's lectures on QED are unique and superb in describing a complex topic in a form suitable for a reader/listener untrained in higher mathematics.
This book gives the ideology behind the theory that won him the Nobel Prize in Physics, it is a must read for anyone interested in particle physics
I have since a long time evinced interest and curiosity in the subject of Theory of Relativity. This book does satisfy my interest and curiosity.
This book is great book for both people are studying physics and people are not, because Dr. Feynman break down QED, so everyone can understand.
Very clear and also entertaining introduction to the subject. QED explains a very great deal of what happens, and Feynman was the master.
Excellent, excellent, excellent. Dr. Feynman had a gift, and it clearly showed at the Investigation of the Challenger Explosion.
a book that is a bit deep but a must read and study about a interesting subject written by a super physics guru, what a life.
Way to much detail in the mathematical procedures but did give an excellent review of current thinking on particle physics.
This was a marvellous stradle between descriptions of  the world of real science and the world of popular science books
Great explanation of quantum electrodynamics, even for those who haven't studied any physics for a long time.
The greatest book about quantum physics for lay people and  aspiring physicists.
He makes it so easy to understand and appreciate quantum path integrals.
Fun read if you have the time and mental energy. Stuff gets complicated.

There is little to say about Feynman's landmark book other than what a brilliant and well written book!  A classic in every sense of the word.  Anyone interested in learning about the wierd world of Quantum Physics should own this book, read this book often and recommend it to others trying to get their heads around QED.  Simply brilliant!

A rigorous but non-mathematical insight into Qed by the master of teaching.  Requires patience and effort but one is rewarded with an understanding of the QED formulation of quantum mechanic.  The introduction in the new edition was worth buying the book a second time.

As the introduction states, the book is intended for students, scholars, and interested lay people. I'm in the last group and found the subject fascinating.  It was written to inform and encourage further study and made plentiful use of graphs to explain the text.

An excellent and very enlightening book. Typical Feynman and even better than his Six easy pieces an Six not so easy pieces. Strongly recommended for those who want an introduction into QED without the background to go into the detailed mathematics.
Well written for both scientists and lay people.

If you enjoy scientific reading, this is a must have. Feynmen is a skilled genius, The only thing that surpasses his genius is his ability to explain complex highly mathematical concepts to the masses with out a hint of math.

In a honest and direct way Feynmann told us about the underlying methods and the basic principles that rule almost all phenomena we have to deal with in ordinary live, no matter how bare and unexpected it could be.
Very good intruduction into QED. Understandable for the non-scientific community! Makes a very difficult theme accessible and makes you want to know -much- more about the subject.
More technical then most books I've read by or about Feynman, but less than others.  His intelligence AND personality comes through in spades.
Good product and good service.
Great Book!  Very well done.

I am an avid reader of this genre (fairly deep works on various fields of science, but not quite up to the level of professional) This one I expected to be a very clear and insightful presentation of the concepts underlying QED.  It is after all, by Feynman himself, reputed to be one of the clearest lecturers ever, and one of the originators of the remarkably successful QED theory. It falls flat.  I think that the book was written directly from lecture notes, and out of the classroom environment the explanations come across as contrived, opaque and endlessly wordy. Frankly, I don't know any more about QED now that before I read it. Sorry to knock the work of a Nobel winner, but that's my take on it.

There is an old expression among monastics: "We aim not to understand God but to immerse ourselves in the mystery of God." This books immerses us in the mystery of quantum physics. While it spares us the advanced math and esoteric details of the experiments and analysis of Feynman's conclusions - it is still technical and can be hard to get through. But it is worth the effort. The strange way light behaves when interacting with matter boggles the mind yet is supported by the evidence. When done reading, I felt simultaneous informed on the fundamental process of reflection and amazed that it can happen at all. Great stuff.
Feynman Classic
Very readable.
Awesome Book.!
A must read!
Unlike Feynman's lecture series, you'll be able to understand every word of the first two of the books three sections. Is a great feeling to understand Feynman.

Tackles one of the big mysteries of physics, Quantum Electrodynamics, in layman's terms. This book is for those people who lack the years of graduate-level Physics, but are still interested in this intriguing subject. Great companion to Six Easy Pieces and Six Not-So-Easy Pieces.

I enjoy Feynman's writings but this one is, frankly, over my head; more in-house tech than i am equipped to handle; mostly math above my level. if you are heading towards a degree in physics and have a good early college math education you'll probably like it.

I was in a collect-Feynman mood in August and acquired much of his output, audio and print, and most gets 5 stars...This one I am unfairly (to him) giving 4 because it darts over my head at a point somewhere near the first third of the book.  Ryk

As advertised, Feynman explains quantum physics in down-to-earth terms, making it very understandable. It is a very valuable resource for anyone who wants to acquire a better understanding of the not-so-intuitive world of quantum physics.

Probably the best book I have read on a science topic.  Nice to have a specialist Dr. R. Feynman was explain his understanding of what nature is without trying to grab my attention with a strange statment.
This book is great for aspiring physicists and interested readers. If you don't have a scientific background you will need a lot of imagination to understand this topic.
A must read for a clear explanation of QED for the masses with practical examples. Beautifully written and belongs on everyone's bookshelf.
Quantum electrodinamics concepts for the layman by a Nobel laureate, famed teacher and science giant! You can get wrong with this...
Understandable for High School graduates who have taken some mathematics.  The writing level is aimed at this group of people.
This is an excellent book. I am not a math pro or anything close but this book lays it out so a lay person can understand it.
Very well and clearly written.  Explains the new concepts of light in layman terms without the use of elaborate equations.
Maybe I'm just saturated with Feynman, but I don't plan to reread this for awhile. Perhaps in a few years...
Feynman's explanations are good and insigtful even for the non physicist, great value. a a a a a a a
Feynman was a great scientists, and a great teacher.
Anything by Richard Feynman is great to own
QED is very quick and easy to read.  Nothing more needs to be said but read it.
Great!
My expectations were for a little more depth. Probably my fault. Things have changed since 1985 in this field, and much more is known. Just wanted a taste of Feynman.
Buying a used book can be a bit risky - but this one came in good condition - as advertised.  Shipping was prompt.  Would buy from them again.
MADE QED EASY TO UNDERSTAND - FROM A MASTER TEACHER AND DISCOVERER.
Exactly what I needed.  Quick delivery!  Very pleased.
this tells me a lot about light that I wanted to know.  Much more to find out however. the end
Way over the amatures head. Not for the casual reader

Good book, but unless you're really into quantum stuff it gets boring quick. I have only made it about half way through and have moved on to other books that were more interesting. Some day I'll finish it probably.
It takes some slogging, but this is pretty good.  If you don't have a lot of physics background, you'll need patience, but your patience will be rewarded.
